Award.AwardTitle: LTREB Renewal: Biogeochemical Mechanisms of Response in the Third Decade of Whole-Ecosystem Experimental Manipulations at the Bear Brook Watershed in Maine (BBWM)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Research at the Bear Brook Watershed in Maine has been conducted for more than 25 years on the effects of atmospheric sulfur and nitrogen deposition on forest, soils, and stream runoff, in a changing climate. Each watershed includes a headwater stream. One watershed is treated bimonthly by helicopter (simulating atmospheric sulfur and nitrogen deposition) and the other is an untreated reference. This project will support the third decade of research, which explores new ecological response mechanisms that can only be investigated by long-term, multi-decadal research.

The broader impacts of this project include the training of undergraduate and graduate students. This research also provides direct evidence of whole-ecosystem responses to chemical treatments that simulate air pollutants, providing results not possible from controlled laboratory studies. This research has identified and verified key factors governing forest response to sulfur and nitrogen deposition, and revealed major gaps in our understanding that are critical to determining the success of current and future influences of the Clean Air Act. Societal concerns about the effects of acid deposition, reactive nitrogen, and climate change on forest ecosystem services grow increasingly important. This research directly addresses those information needs for today and the future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Bear Brook Watershed in Maine is a whole-watershed chemical manipulation experiment established in 1986 to study the effects of acid deposition pollution (excess nitrogen and sulfur) on forests and their associated surface waters. This LTREB grant supported the most recent period of research, at the end of 28 years of experimentation. The East Bear watershed is the reference watershed; the contiguous West Bear watershed received bimonthly helicopter applications of ammonium sulfate to simulate elevated air pollution. From 1987 to 2018, measurements at the East Bear watershed documented improvements in air quality (approximately 70% and 50% lower sulfur and nitrogen deposition, respectively, in precipitation), and improving ecosystem conditions. The benefits of the implementation of the Clean Air Act and Amendments are clear. Approximately 90% of the atmospheric deposition of nitrogen over 28 years has been retained in the East Bear ecosystem.

The treated West Bear watershed revealed a multi-decadal evolution of ecosystem responses, underscoring the importance of long term research, and serving as an analog for what conditions might have been like had the Clean Air Act implementation never taken place. The acidifying effects of the treatment stripped base cations, primarily calcium, from the soils during the first ca. 30 years. Mobilization of soil aluminum, phosphorus, and rare earth elements (REEs) to streams accompanied the higher calcium losses. The nitrogen in the treatments was largely retained by the ecosystem although elevated concentrations of nitrate in the West Bear stream persisted; almost 80% of the total annual nitrogen deposition for 1989-2017 was retained in the watershed. Despite the acidification of soils from the treatment, there was a 24% increase in forest biomass nitrogen due to a fertilization effect, mostly due to a growth response in the hardwoods, with little growth response in softwoods.

During the study, seven undergraduate students, four graduate students, one post-doctoral fellow and other professionals were involved in the project. The research has served as a framework for three K-12 initiatives and curricula. Nearby Old Town High School has developed a ten-year watershed research program on school property, modeled after this project, with ongoing collaboration with scientists from our project.

The Bear Brook Watershed in Maine has provided many insights on basic biogeochemical processes in a northern New England forested watershed, demonstrated responses of ecosystems to changes in atmospheric deposition that informs past and future policy, and is the most intensively studied forest ecosystem in Maine, a state with over 89% in forest cover The data from the project have been used to inform evaluations of forest sustainability and water quality. The Bear Brook Watershed in Maine is one of the case studies used by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency for its national evaluation of secondary air quality standards for nitrogen and sulfur.
